questions.stem: Lewin's three-stage model of change proposes that organizational change proceeds through which sequence?

options.text: Forming, storming, norming
Unfreezing, changing (moving), refreezing
Planning, executing, evaluating
Denial, resistance, acceptance

questions.explanation: Lewin's (1947) change model has three stages: Unfreezing—disrupting the current equilibrium by creating motivation for change (through disconfirmation, survival anxiety, or reducing learning anxiety); Changing (Moving)—introducing new attitudes, behaviors, and processes; Refreezing—stabilizing the new state through reinforcement, policies, and new norms. Schein later elaborated on this model, adding cognitive restructuring through identification and scanning as part of the changing stage. Option A describes Tuckman's group development stages.

questions.stem: Action research, a foundational approach to organization development (OD), is characterized by:

options.text: Laboratory experiments with random assignment to conditions
A cyclical process of diagnosis, intervention, data collection, and feedback leading to further action
Exclusively quantitative survey methods
Top-down implementation of change without employee participation

questions.explanation: Action research (Lewin) is a cyclical process combining research and practice: problems are diagnosed through data collection, interventions are planned and implemented, outcomes are measured, and findings feed back into the next cycle of diagnosis and action. Key features include: collaboration between researcher and organizational members, emphasis on practical problem-solving, participative approaches, and iterative learning. This approach is foundational to OD because it embeds evaluation into the change process and treats change as an ongoing learning cycle rather than a one-time event.

questions.stem: Appreciative Inquiry (AI), as developed by Cooperrider and Srivastva, differs from traditional OD approaches primarily by:

options.text: Focusing on diagnosing and fixing organizational problems
Focusing on identifying and amplifying organizational strengths and positive experiences
Using only quantitative methods for organizational assessment
Implementing change exclusively through top management directives

questions.explanation: Appreciative Inquiry (AI) fundamentally shifts the OD paradigm from deficit-based (what's wrong?) to strengths-based (what works well?). The AI 4-D cycle includes: Discovery (appreciating what gives life to the organization), Dream (envisioning what might be), Design (constructing the ideal), and Destiny/Delivery (sustaining the change). AI is based on the social constructionist assumption that organizations move in the direction of what they study—asking positive questions generates positive change. This contrasts with traditional problem-solving approaches that focus on gap analysis and deficit correction.

questions.stem: Kotter's eight-step model of leading change emphasizes that the first step in successful organizational change is:

options.text: Forming a powerful guiding coalition
Establishing a sense of urgency
Generating short-term wins
Anchoring new approaches in the culture

questions.explanation: Kotter's (1996) eight steps begin with establishing urgency—convincing people that the status quo is more dangerous than the unknown. Without urgency, complacency prevents change. The full sequence is: (1) Establish urgency, (2) Form a guiding coalition, (3) Create a vision, (4) Communicate the vision, (5) Empower broad-based action, (6) Generate short-term wins, (7) Consolidate gains and produce more change, (8) Anchor new approaches in culture. Kotter emphasized that skipping steps or moving too quickly creates problems; most failed changes stumble on the first four steps.

questions.stem: Process consultation, as described by Edgar Schein, is an OD intervention in which the consultant:

options.text: Diagnoses the problem and prescribes a specific solution
Helps the client perceive, understand, and act upon process events in their environment
Takes over management of the troubled department
Conducts employee satisfaction surveys and reports results

questions.explanation: Schein's process consultation model positions the consultant as a facilitator who helps clients develop their own diagnostic and problem-solving capabilities. Rather than providing expert solutions (the 'purchase model') or diagnosing and prescribing (the 'doctor-patient model'), process consultation helps clients observe and understand process events—communication patterns, decision-making, leadership, group dynamics. The goal is building the client system's capacity for self-diagnosis and problem-solving, creating sustainable organizational learning rather than dependence on external expertise.

questions.stem: According to research on resistance to organizational change, which of the following are recognized sources of individual resistance? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Fear of the unknown and uncertainty about outcomes
Loss of status, power, or established routines
Lack of trust in those initiating the change
Universal enthusiasm for any change initiative
Selective information processing (interpreting change through existing beliefs)

questions.explanation: Individual resistance to change stems from: fear of unknown outcomes and uncertainty (A); threatened loss of status, power, routines, or social connections (B); lack of trust in change leaders' motives or competence (C); and selective perception—filtering information about change through existing beliefs and expectations (E). Universal enthusiasm (D) is unrealistic—research consistently shows that resistance is normal and can even be functional when it surfaces legitimate concerns. Effective change management addresses resistance through communication, participation, support, and building trust.

questions.stem: Team building as an OD intervention typically includes which of the following components? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Clarifying team roles and responsibilities
Improving communication and interpersonal processes
Setting team goals and establishing norms
Firing all underperforming team members
Examining and improving group decision-making processes

questions.explanation: Team building interventions address: role clarification—reducing ambiguity and conflict about who does what (A); interpersonal processes—improving communication, trust, and conflict resolution (B); goal setting and norms—establishing shared objectives and behavioral expectations (C); and process improvement—examining how the team makes decisions, solves problems, and manages conflict (E). Team building does not involve simply removing members (D)—it focuses on improving how existing members work together. Research shows team building is most effective when it targets specific team needs identified through diagnosis.

questions.stem: Which of the following are characteristics of a learning organization as described by Senge? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Systems thinking—understanding how parts of the organization relate to each other
Personal mastery—continuous individual learning and development
Shared vision—collective aspiration for the organization's future
Rigid hierarchical control—preventing information flow across levels
Team learning—collective thinking and dialogue skills

questions.explanation: Senge's (1990) five disciplines of a learning organization are: Systems thinking (understanding interconnections and feedback loops), Personal mastery (individual commitment to learning), Mental models (examining assumptions and beliefs), Shared vision (collective purpose), and Team learning (dialogue and collective thinking). Rigid hierarchical control (D) is antithetical to learning organizations, which require open information flow, psychological safety, and cross-level communication. Systems thinking is the 'fifth discipline' that integrates the others.

questions.stem: Survey feedback as an OD intervention involves which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Systematically collecting data from organizational members through surveys
Feeding results back to the groups that provided the data
Using data to identify problems and plan action steps
Keeping results confidential from employees who participated
Comparing results across groups or over time to identify patterns

questions.explanation: Survey feedback (developed at the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research) is a systematic OD intervention: data are collected via standardized surveys (A), results are fed back to participating groups in facilitated sessions (B), groups use data to diagnose problems and develop action plans (C), and comparisons across groups or time periods reveal patterns (E). Keeping results from participants (D) violates the fundamental principle of survey feedback—the intervention's power comes from open sharing and collaborative interpretation of data. Bowers (1973) found survey feedback was the most effective OD intervention compared to several alternatives.

questions.stem: Sociotechnical systems (STS) theory, developed at the Tavistock Institute, emphasizes which of the following principles? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Joint optimization of both social and technical subsystems
Organizations are open systems interacting with their environment
Autonomous or self-managing work groups
Technology should be optimized independently of social considerations
Minimal critical specification—specify only what is essential, leaving workers latitude

questions.explanation: STS theory (Trist & Bamforth, 1951, from the Tavistock coal mining studies) emphasizes: joint optimization—neither the technical nor social system should be optimized at the expense of the other (A); open systems perspective—organizations interact with their environment (B); autonomous work groups—self-managing teams that control their own work processes (C); and minimal critical specification—only essential parameters should be specified, allowing workers maximum discretion (E). Optimizing technology independently (D) is exactly what STS opposes—the coal mining studies showed that introducing new technology without considering social impacts destroyed effective work group dynamics.

questions.stem: Match each OD intervention to the organizational level it primarily targets:
questions.explanation: Process consultation (Schein) primarily targets group-level dynamics—helping teams improve communication, decision-making, and interpersonal processes. Survey feedback targets the whole organization, collecting and sharing system-wide data on attitudes and perceptions. Sensitivity training (T-groups) is primarily an individual-level intervention, enhancing personal awareness of one's impact on others through unstructured group interaction. Structural redesign targets the organizational level by changing formal systems, reporting relationships, and organizational architecture.

questions.stem: Match each change management approach to its primary theorist:
questions.explanation: Lewin's three-stage model (1947) remains foundational to understanding change. Kotter's eight-step model (1996) provides a prescriptive leadership framework for implementing change. Cooperrider's Appreciative Inquiry (1987) offers a strengths-based alternative to deficit-focused change. Schein's process consultation (1969) emphasizes the consultant's role in helping clients build self-diagnostic capacity. These approaches are complementary and often used in combination in OD practice.

questions.stem: For each organizational change strategy, select ALL conditions under which research suggests it is most effective:

columns.text: When there is ample time for the change process
When the crisis is severe and immediate action is required
When resistance stems from lack of information
When employee buy-in is critical for implementation
When employees have relevant expertise to contribute

questions.explanation: Participative strategies work best when time allows, employee buy-in is essential, and employees have valuable input—participation increases commitment and leverages distributed knowledge. Directive strategies are appropriate in crises requiring immediate action where delay is dangerous. Educative strategies work when resistance is based on misunderstanding or lack of information, and sufficient time exists for learning. Kotter and Schlesinger's (1979) framework recommends matching strategy to the situation, considering: urgency, type of resistance, change agents' power, and stakes involved.

questions.stem: For each OD intervention category, select ALL specific techniques that belong to it:
questions.explanation: Human process interventions target interpersonal and group dynamics: team building, process consultation, conflict resolution, third-party peacemaking, and sensitivity training. Technostructural interventions modify organizational structure and work processes: restructuring, job redesign, work design, quality programs (TQM, Six Sigma). Strategic interventions address the organization-environment interface and overall direction: culture change, organizational learning, transformational change, and strategic planning processes. This categorization (Cummings & Worley) helps OD practitioners match interventions to the type of change needed.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Lewin's change theory:

Lewin conceptualized organizations as existing in a state of [BLANK1]—a balance between driving forces (pushing for change) and restraining forces (resisting change). To create change, one can either increase [BLANK2] or decrease restraining forces, though Lewin recommended the latter to avoid increasing tension. The first stage, unfreezing, involves creating [BLANK3] for change by disrupting the current equilibrium. Schein elaborated that unfreezing requires creating [BLANK4]—the feeling that something must change—while simultaneously reducing [BLANK5]—the anxiety associated with trying new behaviors.
questions.explanation: Lewin's force field analysis describes organizations in quasi-stationary equilibrium—seemingly stable but actually balanced between opposing forces. Change requires altering this balance. Lewin preferred reducing restraining forces because increasing driving forces can raise tension and resistance. Schein's elaboration: unfreezing requires survival anxiety (the threat if change doesn't occur) to exceed learning anxiety (fear of the change process). The goal is to reduce learning anxiety through psychological safety, not to increase survival anxiety through threats—creating a safe environment for trying new behaviors.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about OD values and principles:

Organization Development is grounded in [BLANK1] values, emphasizing respect for people and collaborative relationships. A core OD value is that people are most productive when they have opportunities for [BLANK2] in decisions affecting them. The OD consultant maintains a role as [BLANK3] rather than expert prescriber. OD interventions should be based on valid data gathered through [BLANK4]. A fundamental assumption of OD is that organizations are [BLANK5]—complex entities whose parts are interdependent and interacting with their environment.
questions.explanation: OD's value base is humanistic and democratic—respecting human potential and collaborative decision-making. Participation is both a value (people deserve input) and a practical strategy (participation increases commitment and leverages knowledge). The OD consultant serves as facilitator, helping the organization develop its own capacity rather than creating dependency. Action research methodology ensures interventions are data-driven. The open systems perspective recognizes that organizations are complex, interdependent, and in constant transaction with their environment—changes in one part affect other parts.

questions.stem: A large hospital system is implementing an electronic health records (EHR) system. After six months, adoption rates are below 40%, with older physicians citing it as 'unnecessary bureaucracy' and nursing staff reporting that the system slows patient care.
questions.centerQuestion: Using Lewin's framework, what stage of change has the organization failed to adequately address?

options.text: Users don't see a compelling reason to abandon their current workflow
Insufficient communication about why the change is necessary
Users were not involved in the system selection or implementation planning
The technology itself is fundamentally flawed
Create urgency by communicating patient safety data and regulatory requirements
Identify and empower physician champions to model and advocate for the system
Simply mandate use and punish non-compliance immediately
Provide tailored training that addresses specific workflow concerns of each user group

centerOptions.text: Unfreezing—the organization failed to create sufficient motivation for change
Refreezing—the new system was not properly stabilized
The change model is irrelevant to technology implementation

questions.explanation: The primary failure is inadequate unfreezing. Users don't perceive compelling reasons to change (survival anxiety is low), weren't involved in planning (no ownership), and weren't adequately informed about necessity. Lewin and Schein would argue that without sufficient unfreezing, the change cannot proceed—people must first be motivated to abandon current behaviors. Remedies include creating urgency (communicating patient safety benefits and regulatory mandates), using champions (vicarious learning), and providing supportive training (reducing learning anxiety). Punitive mandates alone increase survival anxiety but don't address the root unfreezing failure.

questions.stem: An organization hires an OD consultant to address interdepartmental conflict. The consultant spends two weeks interviewing employees, analyzing communication patterns, then presents a detailed report recommending specific structural changes. Management implements the changes, but conflict actually increases.
questions.centerQuestion: What fundamental OD principle did the consultant violate?

options.text: The consultant used a 'doctor-patient' model rather than process consultation
Employees were not involved in diagnosing problems or generating solutions
The intervention addressed structure without addressing the human processes underlying conflict
Data collection was too thorough and time-consuming

rightColumn.label: How a Process Consultation Approach Would Differ

options.text: Help departments understand their own conflict patterns and dynamics
Facilitate joint problem-solving sessions between conflicting departments
Prescribe a more detailed structural solution
Build the organization's capacity to manage future conflicts independently

centerOptions.text: The consultant used an expert/prescriptive model instead of a participative, process-oriented approach
The consultant collected too much data
The structural changes were the wrong specific changes
The consultant should have been more authoritative

questions.explanation: The consultant used Schein's 'doctor-patient' model (diagnose and prescribe) rather than a process consultation approach (help the client understand and address their own issues). Core OD principles violated: participation (employees weren't involved in diagnosis or solution generation), process focus (structural changes addressed symptoms, not the interpersonal processes driving conflict), and capacity building (the organization didn't develop its own conflict management skills). Effective OD would involve facilitating joint diagnosis and collaborative solution development, building sustainable organizational capabilities.

questions.stem: An OD practitioner is reviewing principles of organizational change. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Lewin's force field analysis suggests that reducing restraining forces is generally preferable to increasing driving forces. (B) Kotter's model emphasizes that anchoring changes in organizational culture should be the first step, not the last. (C) Action research involves a cyclical process of diagnosis, intervention, evaluation, and feedback. (D) Resistance to change is always irrational and should be eliminated rather than understood. (E) The sociotechnical systems approach emphasizes joint optimization of social and technical subsystems. (F) OD interventions should be implemented without data collection to save time.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Lewin recommended reducing restraining forces because increasing driving forces raises tension and can create additional resistance. (C) Action research is iterative and cyclical, combining research with action. (E) STS emphasizes that neither social nor technical systems should be optimized at the expense of the other. Incorrect: (B) Kotter places culture change last (Step 8), not first—culture is the outcome of sustained change, not its starting point. (D) Resistance can be rational and informative, potentially identifying legitimate problems with the change. (F) Data collection is fundamental to OD; interventions should be data-driven.

questions.stem: A graduate student is studying OD interventions. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Sensitivity training (T-groups) aims to increase self-awareness and interpersonal sensitivity through unstructured group interaction. (B) Third-party peacemaking involves an external facilitator helping conflicting parties resolve disputes. (C) Quality of Work Life (QWL) programs focus exclusively on increasing production efficiency without regard for employee welfare. (D) Parallel learning structures create supplemental organizational structures where members learn and innovate before applying changes to the formal organization. (E) Total Quality Management (TQM) emphasizes continuous improvement, customer focus, and employee involvement. (F) Large-group interventions (e.g., Open Space, Future Search) involve many stakeholders simultaneously to accelerate change. (G) OD assumes that organizations are closed systems unaffected by their external environment.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) T-groups (sensitivity training) use unstructured interaction for personal insight. (B) Third-party peacemaking (Walton) facilitates conflict resolution. (E) TQM (Deming, Juran) emphasizes continuous improvement, customer orientation, and participation. (F) Large-group interventions (Bunker & Alban) bring many stakeholders together simultaneously. Incorrect: (C) QWL programs specifically aim to improve employee welfare alongside organizational effectiveness. (D) Description of parallel structures is partially accurate but was not selected because the other four are more clearly accurate. (G) OD is based on open systems theory.

questions.stem: Arrange Kotter's eight steps for leading change in correct sequence:

options.text: Create a vision and strategy for change
Anchor new approaches in the organizational culture
Establish a sense of urgency
Generate short-term wins to build momentum
Form a powerful guiding coalition

questions.explanation: Kotter's sequence (abbreviated to 5 of the 8 steps): (1) Establish urgency—create the motivation for change; (2) Form a guiding coalition—assemble a team with power and credibility to lead the effort; (3) Create a vision and strategy—provide direction and a roadmap; (4) Generate short-term wins—demonstrate early success to build momentum and silence critics; (5) Anchor in culture—ensure new approaches become embedded in organizational norms and values (this comes last because culture change is the outcome of sustained behavioral change, not its precursor). Steps 4 and 5 of the full model (communicate vision, empower action) occur between vision creation and short-term wins.

questions.stem: Arrange the Appreciative Inquiry 4-D cycle in correct sequence:

options.text: Design (constructing the ideal organization)
Discovery (appreciating what gives life to the system)
Destiny/Delivery (sustaining and embedding the changes)
Dream (envisioning what could be)

questions.explanation: The AI 4-D cycle: (1) Discovery—identify what works well, positive experiences, and organizational strengths through interviews and storytelling. (2) Dream—envision the organization's potential based on discovered strengths. (3) Design—create propositions and plans for the ideal organization grounded in what already works. (4) Destiny (or Delivery)—implement and sustain changes through ongoing innovation and learning. The cycle is iterative and collaborative, always beginning with the positive (Discovery) rather than problem identification, which is AI's fundamental departure from traditional OD diagnosis.

questions.stem: Review data from a meta-analysis on the effectiveness of different OD interventions in improving organizational outcomes:

datasets.name: Mean effect size (d) on organizational outcomes

questions.question: Which approach shows the largest effect on organizational outcomes?

options.text: Sensitivity training, because it addresses individual awareness
Multi-component programs that combine multiple intervention types
Structural change alone
All interventions show identical effects

questions.question: What practical implication do these data suggest for OD practitioners?

options.text: Use only sensitivity training because individual change drives organizational change
Comprehensive programs addressing multiple organizational levels and processes are most effective
OD interventions are uniformly ineffective
Structure should never be changed

questions.explanation: Meta-analytic data (e.g., Neuman, Edwards, & Raju, 1989) show that multi-component OD programs produce the largest effects because they address change at multiple levels simultaneously (individual, group, organizational). Survey feedback shows strong effects, supporting data-driven approaches. Sensitivity training shows the smallest organizational-level effects, likely because individual-level changes don't always transfer to organizational outcomes. The practical implication is that comprehensive, multi-faceted change efforts targeting structure, process, and people simultaneously are most effective—consistent with systems thinking.

questions.stem: Examine data on employee resistance and engagement during an organizational change initiative over 18 months:

questions.question: What is the impact of participation on change outcomes over time?

options.text: Participation has no effect on resistance or engagement
High participation dramatically reduces resistance and increases engagement over time
Low participation produces better outcomes
Both groups show identical patterns

questions.question: What does the initial resistance level in the high-participation group (65%) suggest?

options.text: Participation immediately eliminates resistance
Even with participation, initial resistance is normal—the benefit accrues over time
The participation strategy failed
Resistance should never occur in a well-managed change

questions.explanation: The data powerfully illustrate Coch and French's (1948) classic finding that participation reduces resistance to change. However, the initial resistance level (65%) shows that participation doesn't immediately eliminate resistance—some initial reaction is normal. Over time, participation dramatically reduces resistance (to 10%) and builds engagement (to 85%), while the low-participation group remains largely resistant (50%) and disengaged (40%). This supports Lewin's argument that involving people in the change process creates ownership and reduces restraining forces—a core OD value with empirical support.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept according to Lewin's stage of change it primarily addresses:

items.text: Creating dissatisfaction with the current state
Embedding new behaviors into organizational policies
Training employees in new skills and processes
Communicating the urgency and need for change
Aligning reward systems to reinforce new behaviors
Implementing new structures and role definitions
Reducing learning anxiety through psychological safety

questions.explanation: Unfreezing: Creating dissatisfaction (disconfirmation), communicating urgency (survival anxiety), and reducing learning anxiety through safety—all aimed at motivating departure from the status quo. Changing/Moving: Training in new skills and implementing new structures—the actual transition to new behaviors and systems. Refreezing: Embedding changes in policy, aligning rewards, and celebrating success—all aimed at stabilizing the new state and preventing regression. Effective change addresses all three stages; the most common failure is inadequate unfreezing or premature declaration of victory before refreezing.

questions.stem: Categorize each OD intervention according to its primary focus:

items.text: Career development and succession planning programs

questions.explanation: Human process: Team building and conflict resolution focus on interpersonal dynamics and group processes. Technostructural: Job redesign and TQM modify organizational structure and work systems. HRM: Performance management and career development address the organization's people management systems. Strategic change: Culture transformation and organizational learning address the organization's fundamental direction and adaptive capacity. This four-category framework (Cummings & Worley) helps OD practitioners select interventions appropriate to the target of change.
